stem: The nurse is assessing a client admitted to the psychiatric unit following a suicide attempt. Based on the following findings, indicate whether each finding suggests an increased or decreased suicide risk.

rationale.correct:
Increased suicide risk factors include a detailed suicide plan, feelings of hopelessness, and a history of previous attempts. A detailed plan provides the means and intent, hopelessness removes the will to live, and previous attempts indicate a pattern of behavior. These factors significantly elevate the immediate risk of another suicide attempt and require intensive intervention.

Expressing feelings of hope, even amidst other struggles, signifies a protective factor against suicide, as it indicates a reason to live and a belief in a better future.
rationale.incorrect: A vague plan without details does not indicate the immediate means or intent to complete suicide, making it a lower risk than a detailed plan. A lack of previous attempts suggests the client has not previously engaged in suicidal behavior, lowering the immediate risk compared to someone with a history of attempts.
clinicalPearls: Always assess for a specific suicide plan; the more detailed the plan, the higher the risk.
Hopelessness is a major predictor of suicide risk.
A history of suicide attempts is a significant risk factor for future attempts.

questionTrap.trap: Students may confuse vague thoughts of suicide with a concrete plan.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on whether the client has a specific method, access to means, and a timeline for action.

mnemonic.title: IS PATH WARM
mnemonic.expansion: Ideation, Substance Use, Purposelessness, Anxiety, Trapped, Hopelessness, Withdrawal, Anger, Recklessness, Mood Changes

reviewUnits.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
reviewUnits.content: Review factors that increase and decrease suicide risk, including specific plans, history of attempts, and protective factors.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jane Doe, 32-year-old female, admitted today at 14:00 following a suicide attempt at home. She ingested a handful of ibuprofen and called a friend who brought her to the ED. B: Patient reports increasing feelings of hopelessness over the past few weeks related to job loss and relationship difficulties. A: Currently, the patient is tearful and withdrawn. She expresses feeling like a burden to others. Denies current suicidal ideation but admits to having a detailed plan yesterday. Vital signs stable: HR 78, BP 118/72, RR 16. O: Monitor mental status and provide a safe environment. Continue suicide precautions. Offer emotional support and encourage participation in group therapy. Notify provider of any changes in condition. Ensure follow-up appointments are scheduled. Administer scheduled medications as ordered. Reassess suicide risk frequently. Last dose of escitalopram given at 08:00.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 14:00: Patient arrived via ambulance following reported overdose of ibuprofen. Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. 14:30: Placed on suicide precautions. Belongings searched and secured. 15:00: Psychiatry consult initiated. Patient tearful and expresses feelings of hopelessness. 16:00: Patient attended group therapy session. Remained quiet and withdrawn. 17:00: Patient resting quietly in room. Monitored q15 minutes. 18:00: Meal tray provided. Patient ate approximately 25% of meal. Encouraged to eat more. 19:00: Administered escitalopram 10mg PO as prescribed. 20:00: Patient reports feeling slightly more relaxed after medication. Continues to be monitored closely. 21:00: Patient verbalized, 'I don't know if things will ever get better.'

tabs.title: Lab Diagnostics
tabs.content:
CBC: WBC 7.5 x 10^9/L | RBC 4.2 x 10^12/L | Hgb 12.5 g/dL | Hct 37.5% | Platelets 250 x 10^9/L
BMP: Na 138 mEq/L | K 4.2 mEq/L | Cl 100 mEq/L | HCO3 24 mEq/L | BUN 15 mg/dL | Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL | Glucose 90 mg/dL
Toxicology Screen: Ibuprofen detected at therapeutic levels. No other substances detected.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Escitalopram 10mg PO Daily | Last dose: 19:00
Ibuprofen 200mg PO PRN for Pain | Last dose: N/A
